170 Freshmen Enrolled in Largest Class
Hopkins Has Ever Had-- University Moved to New Site at
Cost of $30,000.

By COACH BRENNICK

Three new buildings at Homewood are rapidly nearing completion. These are the Civil Engineering Building, the Johns Hopkins Club and the Student Activities Building.
The Civil Engineering Building
covers a total area of 14,340
square feet. The building is 204
feet in length and comprises three
stories, in addition to the basement. It has been planned so
that at any future time an extensive addition may be made to
the westward to accommodate
either another branch of engineering or to take care of the growth
of the work in the present department.
In the basement, three large
laboratories are located—one each
for the three divisions into which
the work of instruction and re• search in civil engineering is divided. In the central portion of
the building, in the west wing, is
the main laboratory, comprising
a large room, together milli a research room, devoted to investigation work and laboratory Instruction.
On either side of the main
entrance of the building are offi•ces opening out of the corridor
and directly across the corridor
is the main lecture-room—the
largest in the University, by the
way—giving room for seating an
audience of 350 to 400 persons.
The unique feature of the lectureroom, however, is a specially fireproof addition adjoining the lecture-room on the west, which will
be used for the operating of a
moving-picture machine.
The Civil Engineering Building
is similar in style of architecture
to the Mechanical and Electrical
Engineering Building. Prof. C.
J. Tilden, head of the department, had the three types of construction—the pure tile arch ceiling without reinforcement, the reinforced concrete and the steel
construction—used in making a
part of the building, in order to
be able to show the student engineer an actual representation of
each of these different methods.
The Johns Hopkins Club will
be located at Homewood in the
old Carroll Mansion at the entrance to the academic grounds.

The opening of Johns Hopkins
at Homewood brings with it the
largest freshman enrollment in
the history of the University.
There are 170 men in the Class
of 1920; there are 100 men in the
academic department alone,an
increase of 40 over last year's enrollment. This is the first time
in two years that the academic
men have outnumbered the engineers.
At piesent the removal of the
University from the old site has
been practically completed, only
the chemistry library and laboratory and the astronomical laboratory remaining in the Howard
street buildings. All the academic departments are housed in
the large Academic Building,
whereas the engineering courses
are held in the Electrical and
Civil Engineering Buildings. The
cost of moving to Homewood was
about $30,000.
The Academic Building also
contains the president's, dean's,
registrar's and treasurer's offices
and the postoffice. This arrangement is a great improvement over
the old one, where the treasurer
was housed on Howard street,
several squares from McCoy Hall.
The Homewood library has attracted nation-wide attention. The
fact that all department libraries
adjoin the various classrooms and
offices, and the beauty and comfort of the reading-room, combine
to make a system unsurpassed in
any college building. The large
room immediately below the reading-room has been named the
Donovan Room — a reminiscence
of McCoy Hall—in honor of Miss
Carolyn Donovan, who endowed a
professorship of English.
The laboratories are at present
somewhat crowded, but in the
course of a few weeks will become more adjusted to the new
conditions. By that time, likewise, the additional lockers necessary to accommodate all the students will probably be installed.

football team opened its season at
Homewood with Mt. St. Mary's
College and acquitted itself in a
fairly creditable manner. I say,
"fairly creditable" because in the
first half of the game the team
acted as though they had just assembled for the first day's practice and. seemed bent on doing
what they had been tutored not to
do. Some.excuse for this rests on
the fact that the rush line is practically absolutely new; the units
have not as yet played enough together to present any degree of
solidarity. Twenty-four minutes
of actual playing worked wonders
in this direction, so that in the
second half the line played in a
manner that at least indicated
that they were realizing what the
coaches have been trying to instil
into them. The back field, having
played together to a greater extent than the line, for Branham,
Brooks, and Darley have had such
previous experience, gave a better
account of itself throughout the
game. Therefore, the men who
bore the burden and heat of the
day, and the latter was the greater task, deserve credit..

coaches have only 'too full well
appreciated, namely, that we need
more candidates endowed with

REGULATIONS PUT INTO FORCE
Black Ties and Socks the Order of the
Day for 1920—All Rules Must
Be Strictly Observed.

The freshman regulations, as
amended last year, are now in
full operation. The only exception to their complete observance
is the lack of freshman caps,
which will arrive this week.
The regulations for 1916 are
as follows:
1. Freshmen, whenever appearing on the University property,
shall wear the official freshman
cap. This cap shall have a black
left side, a blue right side, a green
lining and a green button. (These
caps have not yet arrived.)
2. Freshmen shall wear socks
and neckties of black only, until
the first-year class has won two interclass championships.
3. No freshman shall walk on
the grass of the University
grounds; neither shall be descend
to the south court by the steps
leading from the upper quadrangle.
4. Freshmen shall occupy seats
in the rooters'section at all games
on Homewood Field. This rule
shall be enforced by a committee
appointed by the sophomore class.
Freshmen shall be excused from
this rule only by permission of
the committee.
5. No freshman shall smoke on
the University grounds, or wear
his hat in any of the University
buildings.
6. No freshman shall.ride in
the elevators in the University
buildings.
7. No student shall wear a let,
ter or any insignia of athletic ability won at a preparatory school.

The 1917 Hullabaloo board, at
its first meeting this year, will, in
,all probability, be confronted -with
the problem of replacing its editor-in-chief. It has been rumored
that J. Trueman Thompson, the
present editor of the book, has decided upon his resignation. When
asked if there was any foundation to the report, Mr. Thompson
admitted that he was considering
the matter very seriously.
Mr. Thompson has started a
store in the Civil Engineering
Building for the furnishing of
technical supplies to the engineering students, and he feels that
the amount of time required for the
management of his investment will
prevent him from giving the time
to the editing of the "Hullabaloo,"
which the task requires. Rather
than slight the book in any way,
lie thinks that a man who has
more time to give should be elected in his place.
Mr. Thompson is an Omicron
Delta Kappa man, and, in the
plans made last year, had already
demonstrated his ability as an
editor. His resignation, if offered,
will, be keenly felt.

Plans for the new School of
Hygiene and Public Health to be
established and maintained at
Johns Hopkins by the Rockefeller
foundation are now thoroughly
matured. Dr. William H. Welch,
the director of the new School of
Hygiene, returned last week from
Europe where since August 7 he
has been investigating institutions
of similar purpose.
The central and principal feature of the school, as Doctor
Welch has pointed out, will be an
institute of hygiene, housed in its
own building, provided with the
requisite laboratories and facilities and its own staff of teachers,
giving their entire time to the
work of teaching and investigating.
Inasmuch as the profession of
the sanitarian and worker in public health, although closely connected is not identical with that
of the practitioner of medicine,
the School of Hygiene and Public
Health, while working in co-operation with the medical school, as
well as with the School of Engineering, will have an independent existence under the University. Opportunities in each will
be available to students of the
other schools.
There will be laboratories of
sanitary chemistry, of physiology
as applied to hygiene, of bacteriology, and provision for industrial
hygiene vital statistics,,a museum
and library.
It is anticipated that mutually
helpful relations will be established with our municipal and
State departments and with „the
Federal public health service,
Whereby opportunities will be afforded for field work and other
practical experience in various
branches of public health work.
Especially advantageous will be
the relations with the International- Health Commission of the
Rockefeller Foundation, which is
engaged in the study and control
not only of hookworm, but also of
malaria, yellow fever, and other
tropical diseases, which will receive due attention in the work of
the Institute.
It' is intended that the school
shall furnish opportunities of a
high order for the cultivation of
the various sciences which find application in hygiene, sanitation,

the training of medical students,

biologists, and others properly prepared who wish to be grounded in

subjects,

those who desire to fit themselves

The Rifle Club of the Johns
Hopkins University has already
begun its season. On Thursday,
at 1 o'clock, a me-king for the purpose of re organizing and discussion was cane] in the Engineering
Building, and arrangements were
made to start practice immediately. On Friday, October 6, the
first match was shot at the old
Richmond Market Range—the
same range as used last year.
The last year's marksmen who
assembled at the meeting on
Thursday decided it best for the
club to enter a series of city
matches. Among those teams
which had previously joined were:
The Mercantile Trust Company,
Chesapeake Riflemen's Club, Maryland State Roads Rifle Club,
Western Maryland, Oriole Rifle
Club, Motor-Arms-Bible Club, and
the Mt. Royal Club.
Participation in these local affairs, it was decided, would greatly add to the interest in shooting,
and in addition, would give the
men more practice for the intercollegiate matches which are to
begin about January 1. The
match of Friday was shot under a
great handicap, since no one in
the club had handled a rifle since
last April. But in spite of this,
The Mercantile's Trust Company's
team ()lily beat the 'Varsity team
by a score of 209 to 206. As a result of the Y. M. C. A. reception
most of the big scorers were unable to attend, causing the entire
burden to be put upon Rowland,
Chisolm and Konze, all of whom,
however, shot high scores.
The arrangement of this city
league is different from that of the
college league. Two divisions are
formed, matches being shot between teams of each division. The
team of each division which wins
the greatest number of matches,
not necessarily the most points, as
in the college league, wins the socalled championship of its division and must shoot against the
highest team of the other for the
city championship.

Death of Hopkins Graduate at Dartmouth College Keenly Felt—Was

Seminary Here.

By BROADUS MITCHELL,
Fellow in Political Economy.
In writing this brief appreciation on behalf of the Political
Economy Seminary of one of its
most recent alumni, it is proper
to speak first of Noble Stockett
as a student. He was not only
painstaking and thorough, but in
in an unusual degree he was original. His research work was in a
difficult field, involving a theoretical and practical inquiry into
the fixation of wages in transportation. His reports to the Seminary were rather longer than
most, and exhibited a diligence in
the survey of material and a
choiceness of expression that are
the marks of finished scholarship.
Every one felt that he had spent
upon his work many hours in addition to what ordinary standards would require. Not infrequently the nature of the study
and the fullness of the material
he brought to light prompted him
to corrections and amendments
of foregoing writers that would
have seemed presumptuous in one
of less integrity as a student. It
was particularly his dissertation
that attracted the economic department of Dartmouth College
to him; the field before him was
rich in possibilities, after the
promising beginning which he had
accomplished.
He was intensely liked by every
member of the Seminary for his
Personal qualities. Courtesy and
cordiality that sprang from the
heart and deepest nature marked
his whole intercourse with his
fellow-students. A sunny geniality went out from him, and compelled friendship. He was a person to draw you into pleasant conversations; how many little episodes in which he figured come
crowding back upon those who
knew him well or slightly!
Noble Stockett did much to add
zest to the department. The
esprit de corps that has distinguished it has been due, to the
presence of such students as he.
It was confidently hoped when he
left the University that his influence would be continued by
visits from time to time.,
If some evidence of the ideals
for which we all strive, if a part
of the enriclunent of our life that
flows from pleasantest social relations, if a fine instance of native
gentility and,sincerity has passed
from us, it, is because Noble Stockett is gone. And though he has
passed too far to be recalled by
vacation or holiday, he is not too
far to be followed by
grateful
recollection by those who knew
him daily.

J. NOBLE STOCKETT, JR., '11.
